keyTakeAways: The Colombian appeals court overturned ex-President Alvaro Uribe’s conviction for fraud and bribery in a decision citing structural deficiencies in the original ruling, including insufficient evidence.
This marks the first time in Colombian history a former president has been convicted of a crime, making the case a landmark in national legal and political history.
The reversal has intensified political divisions, with critics accusing the judiciary of enabling the cover-up of right-wing paramilitary abuses and mass violence during Uribe’s presidency.

Current President Gustavo Petro condemned the ruling as a reflection of a broader pattern of political cover-up linked to drug trafficking and genocide, raising concerns about justice and historical accountability.
Senator Ivan Cepeda has announced plans to appeal the decision to the Supreme Court of Justice, indicating that legal challenges are far from over and the case remains active.

The case has drawn international attention, especially from U.S. President Donald Trump and Secretary of State Marco Rubio, who have criticized Colombia’s judicial system as biased toward left-wing or radical voices.
Petro fears that the reversal may allow Trump-aligned leaders to gain influence in Colombia, particularly through alliances with Uribe’s supporters and opposition to anti-paramilitary policies.

The outcome could significantly shape the 2026 Colombian presidential election, with Uribe’s party and Senator Cepeda both signaling political ambitions, indicating a major shift in political dynamics.
The case reflects deep-seated tensions in Colombia over governance, paramilitary history, and the role of the judiciary in holding powerful figures accountable.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Colombian appeals court has overturned the conviction of former President Alvaro Uribe for fraud and bribery, citing structural flaws in the original ruling and insufficient evidence. This marks the first time a former Colombian president has been convicted of a crime, and the reversal has reignited political controversy, with critics accusing the judiciary of enabling a cover-up of right-wing paramilitary abuses during Uribe’s tenure. The decision has prompted Senator Ivan Cepeda to appeal the ruling to the Supreme Court, and has drawn international attention—particularly from U.S. officials like Donald Trump and Marco Rubio—who have criticized Colombia’s judicial system. The case remains central to the political discourse ahead of the 2026 presidential election, where Uribe’s party and Cepeda may both contest office, and where historical accountability, judicial independence, and geopolitical influence are at stake.
title: Colombian appeals court strikes down ex-President Uribe’s conviction
